On Sunday, June 28, the Washingtonville High School Class of 2020 participated in a town-wide Graduation Car Parade! Starting at one side of Washingtonville, the graduates in their family vehicles looped through Taft Elementary School, drove down Main Street, and entered the High School for a diploma procession line. Students enjoyed cheers, signs, and applause along the way!

Memorable features of the event included posters of the seniors lining Ahern Drive in town, walking across a stage at the High School, photo ops, decorated cars, and more!

Congratulations to all of our graduates. We are so proud of you! #WizardStrong

Good Evening,

As luck would have it, the weather has not been cooperating with us this weekend. Tomorrow is the rescheduled date for the graduation parade. The forecast is calling for good weather early in the day with the threat of rain in the afternoon. We will be moving forward with Sunday’s event, but please keep in mind we may need to make adjustments during the graduation if bad weather moves in earlier than predicted.

The car parade will begin on Sunday at 10:00 am sharp, students should arrive along Ahern Blvd no later than 9:30 am.

Also, the stage will now also be set up on Monday from 8:00 am until 2:00 pm for those seniors interested in taking additional pictures.

We are very much looking forward to celebrating the class of 2020 and know that tomorrow is going to be a special day.

Stay strong Wizard Nation, see you tomorrow,

Mr. Connolly

More than 70 Washingtonville High School and Middle School students were recognized with Sojourner Truth Awards during a county-wide ceremony held at SUNY Orange on Friday, March 6. For the past 30 years, SUNY Orange has honored Sojourner Truth—the highly-regarded 19th century African-American woman who lived in the Mid-Hudson Valley region after escaping from slavery—by giving out awards in her name. It is a celebration of youth, accomplishment, and culture. At the ceremony, WHS Grade 10 student Jade Sampson was honored with a scholarship after being nominated by her teacher Kevin Calderin. In addition to the official event, WMS held a special event for the Middle School students during school hours to celebrate their continued hard work. Students were chosen by teachers, guidance counselors, and administrators because of the positive characteristics they portray at school.

Congratulations to all and keep up the good work!
